titleStmt.title: Policeman and Carp Harran

monogr.title: A Digital Dictionary of Shawi Arabic

prefixDef.p: Private URIs using the teiCorpusHeader prefix are pointers to any element in the SHAWI teiCorpus document.
Private URIs using the share prefix are pointers to audio file residing on the SHAWI network share.
Private URIs using the geo prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a place element in VICAV Geodata list.
Private URIs using the zotid prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a biblStruct element in the TEI export of the VICAV Zotero Group library.
Private URIs using the dict prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a entry in the SHAWI glossary.
Private URIs using the rend prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a rendition element in VICAV rendition library.

spanGrp.span: In former times, fifty or sixty years ago, a superintendent came to Urfa, a policeman; he had been appointed and came to Urfa. You know what ‘appointment’ means? He was appointed and came to Urfa. He started to go on patrol, he was an officer.

In former times, we here in Urfa, as you might know, we used to respect the policeman who came, the superintendent who came, the judge who came, the prosecutor who came, the commander and the soldier who came. There was respect and also a little bit of fear.
As you might know, fifty or sixty years ago, we used to be afraid of the police and of the soldiers as well. I mean there was no lying to him since one should tell the truth.

This policeman, this superintendent came to Abraham’s place (called al-Xalīl). The foreigners, the strangers, as soon as they come to Urfa, as you might know, they immediately walk around Urfa’s fish pond as we say in Turkish; they go to Abraham’s place.

He went to Abraham’s place, looked at the fish and said, “Man, this mullet, this trout, what nice fish they are!” He said it in Turkish. “You people of Urfa, why don’t you eat these fish? Look how good they are!”
For us, these fish are Abraham’s soldiers. We love them, we fear them; they are angels and we venerate them a lot, we respect them, we love them and are afraid of them.
No one dares to insult them, no one dares to speak with them. When we go there we provide them food and water them.
He caught one and put it into a bag. In an ʕillāga as the Syrian Arabs use to call it; we call it pōšēte and pōšēte is a French word.

He took one home. Then, in the evening, he took ghee and started to frying it. He took ghee and it made “chis”, “chis”, “chis” (the sound of frying) until it had become hot. He put the fish in the pan and started frying it.
He kept frying it “chis”, “chis” and suddenly “puuut!” It was the ghee; a piece, a piece of ghee popped into his eye and immediately his eye was burst open. What now! He looked around and said,

“This is, this is meant when the people of Urfa say it is a sin and the like. I did not listen to them, and look, now my eye has burst open!” He called his wife and she said to him, “Now you see it! I told you that it is a sin.”
His wife was faithful, I mean, pious. “Look! Didn’t I tell you? Now you see!” She grabbed the fish, put it into the bag and threw it in the garbage.

From now on this superintendent did not dare to go outside. He avoided people from Urfa because his eye had burst open. He immedietaly terminated his appointment and, by God, he disappeared and moved to another region. He went away. Enjoy it!
